SENT.plain: BACKGROUND: During the last years the classical signs of the acute mastoiditis have changed
Aim of the following study was to examine the change of symptoms as well as the change of incidence
METHODS/PATIENTS: The records of 113 children who received mastoid surgery due to acute mastoiditis were retrospectively investigated
Data covered a regional group of patients during a period of 25 years (1979 - 2003)
RESULTS: Considering the drop of the birthrate from 1991 in the East German countries, there was a significant increase of the incidence of acute mastoiditis
The patients had a mean age of 2,5 years
The classical symptoms like "retroauricular swelling, tenderness and protrusion of the auricle" were only noted by 47 children (41.6 %)
Preoperative complications appeared as facial palsy, abscess and septic lateral sinus thrombosis in 11 children
Bacterial cultures, taken during surgery yielded in 55.7 % Streptococcus pneumoniae
The therapy contained a surgical intervention combined with antibiotics
CONCLUSIONS: An early surgical treatment by mastoidectomy or antrotomy supported by antibiotics represents the safest method to avoid complications
